name: Amelia Prindle
comment info:
Title: Matrimony Madness
I notice that the graph shows the number of weddings per year (each line increasing by .2 million) along with the year that the weddings take place (increasing in 5-year increments). I also notice that the graph begins with a small rise between 1970-1975 and a more steady rise between 1975 and 1985. Along with those increases, there is also a slow decrease going into 2010 and then a significant drop in 2020, when the pandemic hit. The drop occurred in the peak of COVID-19, and then going further into 2021/2022 has begun to rise back up, almost reaching the pre-pandemic numbers by .2 million or so. During the pandemic, people either decided to wait or postpone most weddings for the safety of themselves & their families. As more things begin to open up and vaccination becomes more widely available, people have begun feeling more comfortable holding the gatherings. The last thing I notice is that the forecast is that in 2023 or so, the number of weddings will greatly increase reaching the point of pre-pandemic numbers. I wonder if the predicted numbers will be accurate, or if the new variants will cause the number of weddings to decrease again. I also wonder why there was a decrease in weddings around the years 1975 & 2010, and if they were just due to the ages around and wanting to get married at that time. The last thing I wonder is what happened to the wedding industry during the pandemic, and how they are readjusting now that things are more normal.

name: Max Long
comment info:
On this graph about weddings in the U.S. by each year, I notice a lot of different things. 

Some of the things that stand out the most include:

1. The number of mar weddings taking place declines in 2020. I assume this is because people were not out meeting each other or gathering together due to Coronavirus. This would be the root of why weddings were not being planned.

2. It seems that in the years to come more weddings will occur. Now, I guess that this will be primarily due to people being vaccinated and feeling more comfortable about gathering for large events such as a wedding.

Something else I know that impacted this graph slightly was that in 2015, gay marriage was legalized which explains the small rise in marriages. 

Also, from 1975-1985 there was an increase which I would predict was from the ending of the Vietnam War. And, a decrease happened during the early 2000s which I would predict was due to 9/11.

I wonder why there will be another slight decrease in 2022.

A good title may be: Wedding Wars: Coronavirus vs. U.S. Marriages

name: Alexa
comment info:
The first thing that I noticed about this graph was that it is not a straight line. This is probably because the years do not increase by  one, they increase by 5. So, in order to account for the years in between, they did a step graph which is easier to deduct from compared to a line graph. The second thing I noticed was that the number of weddings in 2020 dropped drastically. Of course this was due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the inability to gather with others safely. However, after around 1987, the amount of marriages is generally decreasing. 

I wonder why the number of weddings in the United States is decreasing. Is it because the value of a wedding is no longer desired? Are people still getting marriage licenses without having a wedding? Is marriage in general just not important to people anymore? This relates to me and my community because less and less people in my life have gotten married. 

Headline: How many people have said "I Do?"

name: Alyssa K, Kylee K, and Zoe H
comment info:
In this graph we noticed that there is an extreme drop in weddings near 2020, which we can only assume is due to COVID-19. Though, it is very surprising that even with the huge drop, there will still around 1.2 million weddings, as most of the world was to be in lockdown. We also noticed that there is quite a bit of regular fluctuation. The graph does not seem to be very linear in the increases or decreases.

Though we understand the huge drop in 2020, we wonder what happened around 1975 and 2008 where there were some drops. Were there any specific factors? We also wondered if some of the decreases were due to less social pressure around marriage? Back in years like 1973, it was very normalized and pushed to be married, but now, in 2022, a lot of people choose to not be married but still be together with someone. So we wonder if this has any factor?

This relates to us and our community because we were able to spark conversation about marriage and how the wedding rates have changed over the years. For example, in our group we talked about how one of our group members mom chooses to not be married, while another member has divorced parents with a step parent, and the last member has married parents. Overall it was extremely interesting to talk about weddings and how each of us and our families feel about them. 

Our catchy headline is: Will you marry me? Weddings over the years.

We also noticed that there is a lot of weddings right after 2020(2021-2023) to make up for all the weddings they pushed back. We wonder how many weddings were originally planned and then were cancelled or pushed back. We also wonder how many of those rescheduled weddings were actually pushed back. We also wonder what months are the most popular for these weddings to occur. Around 2025, we noticed there was a beginning of a decline which makes us wonder if COVID-19 has deterred more people from getting married or if other factors(such as societal norms) that are going to cause the decrease. This relates to us and our community because recently we have received a lot of invitations to weddings that have just been scheduled or that were postponed from the last couple years. A catchy title might be, "Love is in the Graph".

name: Sharon HESSNEY
comment info:
The amount of weddings?  Or, the number of weddings?  What's the difference?

When we can count things, like weddings, we use the word "number."  Example:  The number of weddings is now rebounding.

When we can't count things, like love, we use the word "amount."  Example:  The amount of love has not changed.  

Good to know!

name: Anna
comment info:
I noticed that the number of weddings in the US generally hovered between 2.1 to 2.5 million per year from 1970 up until 2019. Fluctuations, in the numbers align with major events at the time such as the 1973-75 recession and the 2008 financial crisis. However, in 2020, there is a drastic drop in the number of weddings held that year due to the cancellation and postponement of wedding plans in accordance with COVID safety protocols. Perhaps a cause could even be the pandemic preventing people from meeting and developing their relationships. The number of weddings begins to climb the year after and spikes to all-time highs in the next 2 years due to the number of people unable to hold their weddings in 2020.

I mainly find myself curious in the quick resumption of weddings after 2020, as COVID was still going strong then and was and is a persisting problem. Lastly, I find myself curious in the reasoning behind the predicted decrease in weddings from 2023-25 and onwards.

This relates to me and my community because I think people are all aware of the obstacles the pandemic posed, especially in its first year, toward weddings, but it's shocking seeing its extent and the spike in weddings afterward seeing with a graph and numbers.
